This is a dark comedy. If you don't get that from the get-go, you'll miss out on all the fun! There is Christmas Spirit in a dark and funny manner that you will find in very few places. It's one of Robin Williams' last films and a noteworthy performance and I might've been predisposed to like it. I recently watched it again and it was funnier than I remembered. Family holidays for many are disastrous, a forced obligation that everyone tries and fails to make the best of -- let alone helping a 6-year-old boy and his father who still has his own inner sad and disappointed 6-year-old boy trying to hang on to "Santa is real" when everything conspires to interfere with that agenda. And his father, Grandpa is an irascible Scrooge with a port-a-poddy business. There is some poddy mouth, too. There are poignant moments amid the madness and mayhem. If you're in the mood for some crazy people to get through some deep hurt with one another in a funny way, you'll enjoy this atypical Christmas dark night comedy, especially if you've experienced Murphy's law: if anything can go wrong, it will.

It's taken me a while to watch a Robin William's performance again after his death, but I guess time has healed that. Being that it comes from an independent studio, was surprised at the number of known actors in the film.  Guess I gave it three stars as I like Joel McHale, Robin Williams, Lauren Graham, and Candice Bergman (loved the Jeffrey Tambour snowman in the snow globe, kind of weird but interesting).  Thought the film was not the best as far as acting goes, but it offers little material to work with.  It left me a bit empty after watching it.  Didn't want to watch it again right away like other holiday films may have made me feel.  Yes, it's no "It's a Wonderful Life" or "White Christmas".  It felt low budget to me and the only real reason I took a chance on it was to get an UHD 4K copy of it from another source than Amazon.  Fandangonow had it for the same price (UHD) as other services had it in regular HD (or even lower).  I would recommend viewing it if you have either Prime or HULU, but would refrain from buying it unless you really like it or want an UHD 4K copy to see how it looks on your 4K TV (even that isn't that impressive).  Maybe it will grow on me in future holiday viewing times of need, but for now, I wouldn't buy it.......either rent or if you can get it in an included streaming service, go that route.  I don't see it ever becoming a classic, but you never know, I was no fan of "A Christmas Story" either.

If you are looking for a Christmas movie to watch with the kids, keep looking.  If you are looking for an extraordinary cast that makes you care about a deeply troubled set of characters who are doing their best to survive a family Christmas together, then you have arrived.  This was one of Robin WIlliams' last projects, and it show his acting skill as many films have not.  As the patriarch of the clan, he is a grumpy realist who never learned to show affection for his kids.  Candace Bergen is the mother, quietly determined to make her family work no matter the odds.  they are ably supported by an impressive cast.  If you grew up in a large family, the chances are you will recognize at least one of these characters.  The humor deflects well from the potential schmaltz of the constant theme that you can't escape family, because it's a part of you.

I thought it was really good!  And funny, too!  Father and son reconcile over Christmas; there are a lot of movies with a theme of family reconciliation, but they're very sentimental.  THIS movie is for grown-ups.  Also, this film is about a child coming to an age where he realizes that there's no such thing as Santa, versus parents trying to preserve their child's belief in the magic of Christmas.  I think also, this film might inadvertently have dealt with how a parent's alcoholism affects the family.  And there are a lot of cool nuances, too, like when Hobo Santa and Boyd are in a truck stop bathroom, and H.S. tells Boyd that sometimes Christmas miracles are right there in front of you, like looking at yourself in a mirror; Boyd's father, Mitch, has his epiphany when Boyd imitates his behavior, ie, Mitch is looking in a mirror, which renders a Christmas miracle.  And I might say, I don't recall seeing Candace Bergen ever to such a great job of characterization.  And I always thought Robin Williams did a great job when he played dramatic roles; in this one, when he apologizes to his son, it's really poignant.  And finally, Wendi McLendon-Covey and Tim Heidecker are just a treat to watch as Boyd's sister and brother-in-law.

That being said, I loved the true focus of this movie: how does a misunderstood and under-appreciated white collar son amend his relationship with his emotionally constipated blue collar dad? Against the background of a committed long-suffering mother, that journey, humorously told, is the real story and one that is heart-warming to watch. It may not be the reality for a lot of sons and fathers in that position, but a bit of escape not too far outside the realm of probability is the whole point, isn't it?

We all know in real life that true jerk-weed parents never come around and apologize.
